title: (x) Jeanine B. Downie, M.D. mystery italic - Deepdene {Tiff, Paul H}
content:
Deep apologies for the fax-butchered quality. Does anyone have any idea what this might be, or the historical root?

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [churchill\_id.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20131020045851/http:/typophile.com/files/churchill_id.jpg) | 100.18 KB |
author: robb

comments.content:
not even close, nicolai!  
it's [Deepdene Italic](http://web.archive.org/web/20131020045851/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/lanston/ltc-deepdene/italic/) the "g" is a dead giveaway.
\*cursing\* if i could have only stayed logged in!!! heh, good one miss tiff.
They have used the alternate cap M ... now from [Lanston at P22](http://web.archive.org/web/20131020045851/http:/p22.com/lanston/products/Deepdene.html)

Actually, this it looks like the URW version which incorporated the alternate N and M into their italic. This stationary was set before the P22 Lanston revivals were released. Now it's more of a question of which to choose for resetting it...

Which is the "better" Deepdene when set somewhere around 9 pt? I haven't looked at the P22 Lanstons closely and am just downloading the pdf catalog now.

URW's version seems to be a bit more italicized and it has a little less contrast. I would choose Lanston's for both the more upright italic as well as the fact that they are probably a little more faithful to the original. But that's just me.
and Lanston's versions are on sale through MyFonts through today, i believe. and OT versions available...
